scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: This collection, consisting of the correspondence between John Moffitt (1908-1987), poetry editor of America,and Harold Grier McCurdy (1909- ), a professor of psychology at the University of North Carolina and a poet, contains one hundred and eight letters, 1977-1987. In many of the letters they critique each other's poetry, share personal news, and discuss their differences over poetic style and composition.

Several topics of note include: "modern idiom" (July 25, 1977; October 28, 1978; March 20, 1979; and November 15, 1984); Groping for the Right Note,a poem of McCurdy's (February 7,1978); Ezra Pound's influence over modern poetry (February 10,1978); literary fashion (March 24, 1979); On the Death of an Old Ladyby Moffitt (July 7, August 13, September 5 & 27, 1981);Communism (October 6, 1981); gnosticism (February 12 and November 22, 1982); Moffitt's "conversion" from Hinduism to Catholicism (November 5 & December 27, 1983; February 16, 1984; and July 1,1987); the evolution of The Empress Is Not Amused(March 1,1984); Wallace Stevens (March 1, 5, & 10, and April 24, 1984);and Not by Work Alonecontaining printed Moffitt letters.
